Basics

  • Hypertext markup language
  • Language used to create webpages since they first arrived on the web
  • From an older markup language that was used in document publishing (sgml - standard generalised markup language.)
  • Uses tags to provide formatting features. They should be used to provide structure, not presentation.

Working with elements

  • An element is composed of a beginning tag, an ending tag, and the content between the tags. 
 <
div> The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog <
/div>
The <div> element creates a section in the document.

Attributes

The begin tag can contain additional info in the form of an attribute. eg: 

 <
div id="main" class='mainContent'><
/div>

Id = uniquely identifies an element within an HTML document.
Class = specifies a names CSS style that should be applied to the element

Boolean Attributes

The presence of a boolean attribute on an element represents the true value, and the absence of the attribute represents the false value.
Find out more

Eg:
  • Checked - Used with the check box and option button to indicate selection
  • Selected - sed to indicate which option is selected in a drop-down or select list
  • Disables - Used to disable input, text area, button, select, option or opt group
  • Readonly - Used to prevent the user from typing data into a text box password, or text area

Global attribute reference


Self-closing tag

This is a beginning and ending tag all in one.
The rule is to use self-closing tags for tags that cannot have content - this is also called a void element.

Adding attributes

You can define attributes to ensure that you have no existing or future naming conflicts, eg: 

 <span data-customerNumber= ‘123’> Contoso Ltd</span>

Adding comments

Comments help you to document your source and explain bits of code to other people. 
 <!--comment here-->

Common HTML entities

Embedding HTML by using inline frames

You can use the <iframe> element to embed an inline frame that contains an HTML element within the current HTML document. This can be useful when you want to create a header for the website.
This is a HTML document embedded in another html document. This behaves like an inline image, but can have a scrollbar associated with that pages website.
The sandbox attribute prevents (javascript)scripts from being run. e.g:

<iframe src= “demo_iframe_sandbox.htm” sandbox> - the script won’t run 
                          <iframe src= “demo_iframe_sandbox.htm”> - script will run as normal

allow-forms: Enables forms
allow-same-origin: Allows the content to be treated as being from the same origin instead of forcing it into a unique origin
allow-scripts: Enables scripts except pop-ups
allow-top-navigation: Allows the content to navigate its top-level browsing context

Semantic elements and why you should use them

You should use semantic elements carefully so that you only use an element for it’s intended purpose.
If you need a custom element - use the <div> or <span> tag and add a class or id name that defines what it is.

HTML Layout Container

Using the <header> element


  • The <header> should contain <h1> to <h6>, referred to as an <hn> - moving forward element.
  • You can also have other content within the <header> element, such as company logos or navigational links.
  • You can also have multiple header elements within a HTML document, as in a header for each article.
  • The <header> element can also contain the <hgroup> element, which provides the ability to group together a bunch of <hn> tags (<h1> <h2> etc).
  • The <hgroup> element doesn’t have to be contained within a <header>, it can be used outside - mainly used for subtitles and alternative links.
  • If the <header> is just an <h>> element, and contains no other content, you don’t need the <header> tag

Using the <nav> element


  • The <nav> element is used to group together navigational links, i.e for a menu.
  • It can also be used for side-related content.

Using the <aside> element


  • The <aside> element is used to wrap secondary content when used for side bars.
  • This can be where the adverts and other site-related content goes.
  • When the <aside> is in an article it should contain content only slightly relevant to the content within the article.

Using roles


  • Roles can provide specific meaning to screen readers for accessibility purposes
  • There are parent role classes and child role classes, that inherit from role classes.

Documenting code

When documenting code on the HTML page, the <code> and <samp> elements provide meaning. 
<code class= "keepWhiteSpace">
                      sayHello("random");
                          function sayHello(name){
                          alert('hello ' + name);
                          }
                          </code>
<samp class = "keepWhiteSpace">
                      Hello random
                      <samp>

The <code> element is used to define code, whereas the <samp> element defines the output of the code.
As the style might not be compatible with all browsers you might have to use the <pre> element to prevent white space normalisation to make sure the page looks like this - 


                      sayHello("random");
                      function sayHello(name){
                          alert('hello ' + name);
                      }

To display whitespace in CSS you would use the <pre> element.


                      <pre>
                          <code class= "keepWhiteSpace">
                              sayHello("random");
                                  function sayHello(name){
                                  alert('hello ' + name);
                                  }
                          </code>
                      </pre>

Working with tables

You can use the <table> element with the <tr> element to create table rows.
<td> - table details/table cells.

Tables shouldn’t be used for the page layout, only for the layout of data - as maintaining the table layout in html is more difficult than styling it separately in CSS. 


                      <table>
                          <tr>
                              <td>1957</td>
                              <td>Ford</td>
                              <td>Thunderbird</td>
                          </tr>
                          <tr>
                              <td>1958</td>
                              <td>Chevrolet</td>
                              <td>Impala</td>
                          </tr>
                      </table>
